issue.title: Artifacts when rendering to a texture

labels.name: C-Bug
labels.description: An unexpected or incorrect behavior

labels.name: S-Needs-Triage
labels.description: This issue needs to be labelled

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
## Bevy version

`0.15.0`

## \[Optional\] Relevant system information

```ignore
`AdapterInfo { name: "AMD Radeon RX 550 / 550 Series (RADV POLARIS12)", vendor: 4098, device: 27039, device_type: DiscreteGpu, driver: "radv", driver_info: "Mesa 24.0.6", backend: Vulkan }`
```

## What you did

Here's a link to a reproduction repo: https://github.com/musjj/camera_texture_bug. The bug is also visible in the official example: https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/blob/release-0.15.0/examples/2d/pixel_grid_snap.rs, but it's less noticeable due to all the movement.

Run the application with `cargo run` and resize the window a little bit.

## What went wrong

When the scene is rendered to a texture, artifacting occurs on certain window sizes, despite the zoom of the camera and the size of the texture being unchanged. 

Note that the scale factor is *pixel-perfect*, so there shouldn't be any artifacting happening.

## Additional information
![artifact](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/assets/72612857/f881eae5-cb2b-4a57-b677-ed0fd5e4048d)

![artifact_redlined](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/assets/72612857/3cefe07f-e942-4798-acf0-2241b294fb9d)

Here's a video demonstrating the artifacting:

[no_audio.webm](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/assets/72612857/5df19566-8b06-4ea0-818b-dc4a69215881)

body:
I did happen to notice this back right before 0.15.0 was released, specifically in 0.15.0-rc3 when running the pixel_grid_snap.rs example. When I did a git bisect to see which commit it started it on, it ended up on this particular one: #15969.

It still happens to me on release-0.15.0 as well, although strangely I can only reproduce it on Linux; on Windows I can't seem to ever produce the effect (although resizing the window doesn't update quite the same where I can see it resize to each pixel as I drag, I'd have to drag and let go to see it which means I might be missing it at some particular window size)

As for the System and Adapter info:
```SystemInfo { os: "Linux rolling Arch Linux", kernel: "6.12.3-arch1-1", cpu: "AMD Ryzen 9 5900X 12-Core Processor", core_count: "12", memory: "31.3 GiB" }```
```AdapterInfo { name: "AMD Radeon RX 6900 XT (RADV NAVI21)", vendor: 4098, device: 29615, device_type: DiscreteGpu, driver: "radv", driver_info: "Mesa 24.3.1-arch1.2", backend: Vulkan }```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/03eec606-68b7-48ce-9522-b4f71df1d6e6)

You can see the tearing near the bottom left of the mesh in the pixel_grid_snap.rs example

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/33081915-1341-462f-b132-90f04e6b7b23)

@sophrosyne97 

THANK YOU for the bisect, that was it! It looks like that it's a rounding bug, applying this patch fixes the issue:

```patch
diff --git a/crates/bevy_render/src/camera/projection.rs b/crates/bevy_render/src/camera/projection.rs
index 7deb061..05271c1 100644
--- a/crates/bevy_render/src/camera/projection.rs
+++ b/crates/bevy_render/src/camera/projection.rs
@@ -494,10 +494,10 @@ impl CameraProjection for OrthographicProjection {
         let origin_y = projection_height * self.viewport_origin.y;
 
         self.area = Rect::new(
-            self.scale * -origin_x,
-            self.scale * -origin_y,
-            self.scale * (projection_width - origin_x),
-            self.scale * (projection_height - origin_y),
+            (self.scale * -origin_x).round(),
+            (self.scale * -origin_y).round(),
+            (self.scale * (projection_width - origin_x)).round(),
+            (self.scale * (projection_height - origin_y)).round(),
         );
     }
```

But I'm not sure how "correct" this patch is. If you want to open a PR, go ahead!

@musjj 

No problem! That patch does solve the tearing issue for me, but I still unfortunately seem to get some form of pixel distortion when I resize the window. Specifically, as I resize the window I can see some of the pixels changing in size such that one pixel can appear more "smushed" than another, and all the pixels of a sprite seem to be kind of shifting around in size which I didn't experience in 0.14.2. Unfortunately I have to leave for work soon, but when I come back I'll try to take some webms to make things more clear and try to tinker with it.

You're right, I'm noticing that too. I tried to reproduce it in `0.14` and it works perfectly there like you said. No tearing, no pixel shifting. You can try out my repro here: https://github.com/musjj/nearest_filter_regression. There's a `0.14` and `0.15` branch.

I first thought that the pixel shifting is necessary because the sprite and window pixels aren't aligned. But I guess there's a better way to deal with this as shown in `0.14`.

Yep, works for me as well! 

Much appreciated, this issue was bothering me quite a bit :smiling_face_with_tear: 

Nice job!

issue.title: Fix rounding bug in camera projection

labels.name: A-Rendering

labels.name: S-Ready-For-Final-Review

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

Fixes #16773

## Solution

https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/15969 introduces a regression that causes image tearing when `ImageFilterMode::Nearest` is used as the sampler. Rounding the origin fixes the issue.

Credits to @sophrosyne97 for bisecting and finding the commit that broke it.

## Testing

You can test it with this repository: https://github.com/musjj/nearest_filter_bug

```bash
git clone https://github.com/musjj/nearest_filter_bug
cd nearest_filter_bug
echo '[patch.crates-io]\nbevy = { git = "https://github.com/musjj/bevy.git", branch = "rounding-bug" }' >>Cargo.toml
sed -i -e 's/0.15.0/0.15.0-dev/' Cargo.toml
cargo update && cargo run
```
Gradually resize the window to various sizes, while paying attention to the sprite and font. No tearing should occur on any window resolution, even on odd numbers.

Tested on Linux with Gnome. Tests on other platforms would be appreciated.

---

## Showcase

Before:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/785edeae-7b28-4735-bb8e-d7f79eb09ac2)


After:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9288bc45-a3cf-4e4e-b941-85a00844c627)

issue.body:
## Bevy version

main, bisected to #16828

## Relevant system information

SystemInfo { os: "MacOS 14.5 ", kernel: "23.5.0", cpu: "Apple M1 Max", core_count: "10", memory: "64.0 GiB" }
AdapterInfo { name: "Apple M1 Max", vendor: 0, device: 0, device_type: IntegratedGpu, driver: "", driver_info: "", backend: Metal }

Scale Factor 2

## What you did

`cargo run --example projection_zoom`.

See also `orthographic`, `camera_sub_view`, `custom_primitives`.

## What went wrong

Projection is noticeably off-center.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b71a2e26-8e7f-461e-885e-50b735385893)

## Additional information

Caught by [`bevy-example-runner`](https://thebevyflock.github.io/bevy-example-runner/).

https://pixel-eagle.com/project/b25a040a-a980-4602-b90c-d480ab84076d/run/5991/compare/5988?screenshot=3D%20Rendering/orthographic.png

I suspect that rounding needs to happen *after* scaling.

issue.title: Change `OrthographicProjection::area` creation to use `Rect::from_center_half_size`

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

labels.name: C-Code-Quality
labels.description: A section of code that is hard to understand or change

labels.name: C-Usability
labels.description: A targeted quality-of-life change that makes Bevy easier to use

labels.name: D-Straightforward
labels.description: Simple bug fixes and API improvements, docs, test and examples

labels.name: S-Needs-Review
labels.description: Needs reviewer attention (from anyone!) to move forward

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

Changing the creation of `OrthographicProjection::area` in `OrthographicProjection::update` to use `Rect::from_center_half_size` instead of `Rect::new` will decrease the likelyhood of an error on the calculation to shift the center of the view.

## Solution

Change the creation of `OrthographicProjection::area` in `OrthographicProjection::update` to use `Rect::from_center_half_size`.

## Testing

Ran the examples mentioned on #16856

## Showcase
`orthographic` example
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d3bb1480-5908-4427-b1f2-af8a5c411745)

`projection_zoom` example
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e560c81b-db8f-44f0-91f4-d6bae3ae7f32)

`camera_sub_view` example
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/615e9eb8-f4e5-406a-b98a-501f7d652145)

`custom_primitives` example
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8fd7702e-07e7-47e3-9510-e247d268a3e7)

issue.body:
This reverts commit ae522225cdb6af6159eeec6490c5d27e0e6cf504.

# Objective

Fixes #16856

## Solution

Remove rounding from `OrthographicProjection::update`, which was causing the center of the orthographic projection to be off center.

## Testing

Ran the examples mentioned on #16856 and code from #16773

## Showcase
`orthographic` example
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d3bb1480-5908-4427-b1f2-af8a5c411745)

`projection_zoom` example
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e560c81b-db8f-44f0-91f4-d6bae3ae7f32)

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/615e9eb8-f4e5-406a-b98a-501f7d652145)
